messages.content: What Hadith about benefit from doing handwork and doing handwork over begging

Here are the key aḥādīth people cite about earning by one’s own hands and avoiding begging:

1) # Working with your own hands is best  
“**Nobody has ever eaten a better meal than that which he earned by working with his own hands.** Indeed, Prophet Dāwūd used to eat from the work of his own hands.”  
Arabic (short phrase): **ما أكل أحد طعامًا قط خيرًا من أن يأكل من عمل يده**.  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 2072** (also 3417 re: Dāwūd), and in Sunan al-Nasā’ī. citeturn0search2turn0search5turn0search12

2) # Earning (even humble work) is better than asking  
“**It is better for one of you to take a rope, carry a bundle of firewood on his back and sell it**—and Allah will preserve his dignity—**than to ask people who may give him or withhold.**”  
Arabic (short phrase): **لَأَنْ يَحْتَطِبَ أَحَدُكُمْ حُزْمَةً عَلَى ظَهْرِهِ خَيْرٌ لَهُ مِنْ أَنْ يَسْأَلَ**.  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 1470–1471**; also in **Riyāḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn 539**. citeturn0search3turn0search6turn0search4

These narrations are the classic proofs encouraging **handwork, self-reliance, and preserving dignity** over begging. If you’d like, I can format them for a handout with Arabic + English + references.
Can you do it and find others similar in English and Arabic?

Absolutely, Bilal — here’s a clean, sharable mini-handout with short Arabic + English for the core narrations that praise earning by one’s own hands and discourage begging (except when truly necessary). Each item has a reliable reference.

---

## 1) Earn with your own hands
**Arabic (short):**  
**ما أكلَ أحدٌ طعامًا قطُّ خيرًا من أن يأكلَ من عملِ يدِه، وإنَّ نبيَّ اللهِ داودَ كان يأكلُ من عملِ يدِه.**  
**English (short):**  
“No one ever ate better food than from what his own hands earned. Prophet Dāwūd used to eat from the work of his own hands.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 2072.** citeturn2view1

---

## 2) Handwork is better than asking
**Arabic (short):**  
**لَأَنْ يَأخُذَ أحدُكم حبلَه فيَحْتَطِبَ على ظهرِه خيرٌ له مِن أن يأتيَ رجلًا فيسأله أعطاه أو منعه.**  
**English (short):**  
“It is better for one of you to take a rope, gather firewood on his back and sell it than to ask someone who may give or withhold.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 1470** (also in **Muslim**). citeturn2view0

---

## 3) The upper hand (giving) is better than the lower (taking)
**Arabic (short):**  
**اليدُ العُليا خيرٌ من اليدِ السُّفلى… ومن يستعفِفْ يُعِفَّهُ اللهُ، ومن يستغنِ يُغْنِهِ اللهُ.**  
**English (short):**  
“The upper hand is better than the lower… Whoever refrains from asking, Allah will preserve his dignity; whoever seeks self-sufficiency, Allah will enrich him.”  
— **Al-Bukhārī**; **Riyāḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn 296.** citeturn2view2

---

## 4) Refraining from asking brings contentment
**Arabic (short):**  
**ومن يستعفِفْ يُعِفَّهُ اللهُ، ومن يستغنِ يُغْنِهِ اللهُ، ومن يتصبَّرْ يُصبِّرْهُ اللهُ.**  
**English (short):**  
“Whoever refrains from asking, Allah will make him content; whoever seeks to be self-sufficient, Allah will make him so; whoever is patient, Allah grants him patience.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 1469.** citeturn2view3

---

## 5) Begging is only lawful in three cases (Qabīṣah hadith)
**Arabic (short):**  
**إنَّ المسألةَ لا تَحِلُّ إلا لِأحدِ ثلاثةٍ…** *(دينٌ تحمَّلَه، أو جائحةٌ أتت على مالِه، أو فاقةٌ يشهد بها ثلاثةٌ من ذوي الحِجَى).*  
**English (short):**  
“Begging is not lawful except for three: one who assumed a debt (to reconcile others), one whose wealth was destroyed by calamity, or one in dire poverty verified by three sensible people.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim 1044**; **Riyāḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn 535.** citeturn2view4

---

## 6) Honor in honest trade (virtue of earning)
**Arabic (short):**  
**التاجرُ الصدوقُ الأمينُ مع النبيِّينَ والصِّدِّيقينَ والشهداءِ.**  
**English (short):**  
“The truthful, trustworthy merchant will be with the Prophets, the truthful, and the martyrs.”  
— **Jāmiʿ al-Tirmidhī 1209 (ḥasan).** citeturn3search0

---

What else from the religion Hadith and tradition encourages crafts

Love this theme. Beyond “earn from your own hands” and “better than asking,” here are more Qur’ān/Ḥadīth/traditions that uplift **crafts, handwork, and dignified labor**—each with short Arabic + English and a solid source.

---

### 1) The Prophet served at home (mending, stitching)
**Arabic (short):**  
**كانَ في مِهْنَةِ أهلِهِ… يَخْصِفُ النَّعْلَ، ويَرْقَعُ الثَّوْبَ، ويَخِيطُ.**  
**English (short):**  
“He used to be in the service of his family… mending sandals, patching and sewing.”  
— **Al-Adab al-Mufrad 540; also Bukhārī: ‘He served his family.’** citeturn0search6turn0search14turn0search0turn0search8

---

### 2) Prophet Zakariyyā was a **carpenter**
**Arabic (short):**  
**كانَ زكريَّاءُ نَجَّارًا.**  
**English (short):**  
“Zakariyyā was a carpenter.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim 2379; Riyāḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn 541.** citeturn1search1turn1search9

---

### 3) Prophet Dāwūd taught metalwork (armour)  
**Arabic (Qur’ān 34:11, short):**  
**أَنِ اعْمَلْ سَابِغَاتٍ وَقَدِّرْ فِي السَّرْدِ…**  
**English (short):**  
“‘Make full coats of mail and measure well the links…’”  
— **Qur’ān 34:10–11 (with tafsīr explaining the craft).** citeturn1search14turn1search10turn1search2

---

### 4) Best earnings: **honest trade or one’s own hands**
**Arabic (short):**  
**أفضلُ الكسبِ بيعٌ مبرورٌ وعملُ الرَّجلِ بيدِه.**  
**English (short):**  
“The best earnings are an honest sale or a man’s work with his hands.”  
— **Musnad Aḥmad 15836 (graded ḥasan by many).** citeturn0search4

---

### 5) Zaynab (wife of ʿAbdullāh b. Masʿūd) **earned by hand** and gave charity  
**Arabic (gist):**  
**وكانت زينبُ تَصنَعُ بِيَدِها وتُنفِقُ على ابنِ مسعودٍ ويتامى في حَجْرِها.**  
**English (short):**  
“Zaynab used to provide (from her handiwork) for Ibn Masʿūd and the orphans in her care.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 1466, 1462.** citeturn0search1turn0search9

---

### 6) Pay workers promptly (respect for labor)
**Arabic (short):**  
**أَعطُوا الأجيرَ أجرَهُ قبلَ أن يَجِفَّ عَرَقُه.**  
**English (short):**  
“Give the worker his wages before his sweat dries.”  
— **Sunan Ibn Mājah 2443.** citeturn0search5turn0search13

---

### 7) The Prophet **paid the cupper** (professional craft)  
**Arabic (short):**  
**احتجمَ رسولُ اللهِ وأعطى الحَجَّامَ أجرَه.**  
**English (short):**  
“The Messenger of Allah was cupped and gave the cupper his wage.”  
— **Sunan Abī Dāwūd 3423; Muslim 1577a (Abū Ṭaybah).** citeturn2search1turn2search10

---

### 8) “Upper hand” is better (self-reliance over taking)  
**Arabic (short):**  
**اليَدُ العُليا خَيرٌ مِنَ اليَدِ السُّفلى…**  
**English (short):**  
“The upper hand is better than the lower…”  
— **In the collections incl. Riyāḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn.** citeturn0search10

---

## Notes on a popular maxim
You often hear: **«إنَّ اللهَ يُحبُّ إذا عملَ أحدُكم عملًا أن يُتقِنَه»**  
(“Allah loves that when you do a job, you do it with excellence/itqān.”)  
This wording circulates widely, but its **chains are weak**; still, it expresses a sound *value* reflected in the texts above (esp. Qur’ān 34:11’s precision in craft and the Prophet’s own mending/housework). citeturn0search7turn0search15

---

What's the hadith about not rushing? It's like, is there more than one about taking things and planning and doing things with conscious awareness?

Totally—there are several clear texts about **not rushing**, **deliberation (al-anāh)**, careful planning, and acting with **gentleness (rifq)**. Here’s a compact, bilingual set with sources:

### 1) “Deliberation is from Allah; haste is from Satan”
**العربية (قصير):**  
**الأناةُ من اللهِ، والعَجَلةُ من الشيطانِ.**  
**English (short):**  
“Composure/deliberation is from Allah, and haste is from Satan.”  
— **Jāmiʿ al-Tirmidhī 2012** (hasan). citeturn0search0turn0search5turn0search15

### 2) Two qualities Allah loves: forbearance & deliberation
**العربية (قصير):**  
**إنَّ فيكَ خَصْلَتَيْنِ يُحبُّهُما اللهُ: الحِلْمُ والأناةُ.**  
**English (short):**  
“You have two traits Allah loves: forbearance and deliberation.”  
— To **al-Ashajj ʿAbd al-Qays**; **Ibn Mājah 4187** (also in other narrations). citeturn0search1turn0search11

### 3) Gentleness beautifies everything
**العربية (قصير):**  
**إنَّ الرِّفقَ لا يكونُ في شيءٍ إلا زانَه، ولا يُنزعُ من شيءٍ إلا شانَه.**  
**English (short):**  
“Gentleness is not in a thing except it beautifies it; and when removed, it disgraces it.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim 2594**; also in **Abū Dāwūd 4808**. citeturn0search2turn0search17

### 4) Don’t rush answered prayers
**العربية (قصير):**  
**يُستجابُ لأحدِكم ما لم يَعجَلْ، يقولُ: دعوتُ فلم يُستجَبْ لي.**  
**English (short):**  
“Each of you will have his supplication answered so long as he is not hasty and says: ‘I prayed but wasn’t answered.’”  
— **Bukhārī 6340; Muslim 2735**; also **Ibn Mājah 3853**. citeturn0search3turn0search13

### 5) Verify—don’t rush to pass things on
**العربية (قصير):**  
**كَفَى بالمرءِ كذبًا أن يُحدِّثَ بكلِّ ما سمعَ.**  
**English (short):**  
“It is sufficient falsehood for a person to repeat everything he hears.”  
— **Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Muqaddimah (Intro) 5/8.** citeturn0search4turn0search9

### 6) Qur’ān on human haste (two anchors for reflection)
**21:37:** **خُلِقَ الإِنسَانُ مِنْ عَجَلٍ** — “Humankind is made of haste.” citeturn1search0turn1search8  
**17:11:** **وَكَانَ الإِنسَانُ عَجُولًا** — “Man is ever hasty.” citeturn1search1turn1search5
